description: Noun is borrowed from Latin mandātum (“a charge, order, command, commission, injunction”), neut of. mandātus, past participle of mandāre (“to commit to one's charge, order, command, commission, literally to put into one's hands”), from manus (“hand”) + dare (“to put”). Compare command, commend, demand, remand.
The verb is from the noun.

entries.meaning: An official or authoritative command; an order or injunction; a commission; a judicial precept; an authorization.
(politics) The order or authority to do something, as granted to a politician by the electorate.
(Canada) A period during which a government is in power.

definitionGroups.group: (historical) An order by the League of Nations to a member nation to establish a government responsible for a conquered territory, as the colonies of Germany after World War I.

verbs.description: mandate (third-person singular simple present mandates, present participle mandating, simple past and past participle mandated)

entries.meaning: (uncommon) Alternative form of man date: a date between two men.
examples: Moss: Oh, he's long gone, although Roy's got a mandate with him.Roy: It is not a mandate. I am not a man-woman. We are not married. I am not your wife!
